awd_titl_txt: Learning Experiences and Progression Support for Community College Students Pursuing  Biological Sciences Degrees
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will contribute to the national need for skilled scientists, mathematicians, engineers, and technicians.  It will do so by providing scholarships and other supports to twenty high-achieving, low-income undergraduate students at Seminole State College.  The Scholars will pursue Associate of Arts degrees in biology-related fields.  The project will provide Scholars with supports to increase their success in introductory and higher-level biology courses.  Scholars will also receive a customized guided pathway of coursework that is aligned with their academic and career goals.  Other supports include research opportunities and mentoring by faculty who have cultural responsiveness training.  The project expects that these supports will decrease the amount of time Scholars need to achieve a transferrable Associate of Arts degree.  It also expects that Scholars will be more likely to successfully transfer to four-year institutions, where they will earn four-year degrees.  Seminole State University has an ethnically and racially diverse student body, as well as a high proportion of first-generation and lower-income students.  By increasing academic success of a diverse group of Scholars, this project will contribute to building a stronger and more capable STEM workforce.

The overall goal of this project is to increase STEM degree completion of low-income, high-achieving undergraduates with demonstrated financial need.   The specific aims include increasing the: 1.  Success of Scholars in first semester biology; 2. Enrollment and success of Scholars in upper-division biology courses; 3. Retention and graduation rate of Scholars; and 4. Successful transfer and post-transfer success of Scholars.  Beyond the impact on Scholars, the project expects the proposed project activities will improve the STEM learning environments at Seminole State, thus benefiting many students at the college, particularly those from underrepresented groups.   The project will generate new knowledge through program evaluation and through replication of a 2014 research study by Harackiewicz and colleagues, which focused on increasing the achievement of first-generation students in college biology.  Data collected through these efforts will contribute to the body of knowledge about the complexities of implementing high impact education practices that help diverse STEM students succeed. This project is funded by NSF’s Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics program, which seeks to increase the number of low-income academically talented students with demonstrated financial need who earn degrees in STEM fields. It also aims to improve the education of future STEM workers, and to generate knowledge about academic success, retention, transfer, graduation, and academic/career pathways of low-income students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Transforming STEM Education: Seminole State College’s LEAPS and BOUNDS SSTEM Program

The National Science Foundation S-STEM program titled “Learning Experiences and Progression Support for Community College Students Pursuing Biological Sciences Degrees (LEAPS and BOUNDS) at Seminole State College of Florida (SSC), demonstrated exceptional success in advancing opportunities for academically talented students pursuing biology-related degrees. This five-year initiative served 41 students, addressing critical challenges in access, retention, and success within STEM fields.

The program’s strategic approach integrated financial support, evidence-based academic interventions, and mentorship to ensure students thrive through every stage of their academic journey. Its mission extends beyond academics, fostering leadership, professional development, and research opportunities that prepare students to contribute meaningfully to STEM industries and communities.

Major Goals and Achievements

  1. Increase Biology I Course Success Rates: Achieve 20% higher pass rate for Biology I (a gateway course) than the baseline metrics.
    • 90% success rate in General Biology I (compared to a baseline of 54%).
    • Among Black and Latinx students, pass rates reached 89% and 79%, respectively, demonstrating the program’s effectiveness in closing achievement gaps.
  2. Increase Retention and Graduation Rates: Achieve a 10% higher fall to fall retention and 2-year graduation rates for underrepresented STEM students compared to baseline.
    • Achieved a Fall-to-Fall retention rate of 90%, significantly exceeding the baseline of 62.1%.
    • Two-year graduation rates soared to 73.5%, more than ten times the baseline of 6.4%.
  3. Facilitate transfer to Advanced Education: Ensure at least 25% of SSTEM scholars graduate successfully and transfer to 4-year institutions.
    • 56% of graduates transferred to four-year institutions, exceeding the baseline transfer rate of 2.1% by more than tenfold.
  4. Innovative Research Engagement and Dissemination
    Students participated in groundbreaking research on healthcare disparities, presenting findings at prestigious conferences such as the American Association for Cancer Research, Florida Undergraduate Research Conference, and the Latino Medical Student Association’s SALUD Symposium.

 

 

 

Research and Professional Development

The LEAPS and BOUNDS S-STEM program’s emphasis on undergraduate research has been pivotal. Students explored critical topics like disparities in cancer outcomes, leveraging resources such as the SEER database and advanced analytics tools. Notable partnerships also emerged from this grant, such as participation in the AIM AHEAD initiative.  The Artificial Intelligence/Machine Learning Consortium to Advance Health Equity and Researcher Diversity provided training for faculty learned to better develop healthcare disparity projects for students at SSC.  Faculty integrated cutting-edge techniques, including AI and data analytics, into student training, ensuring relevance in today’s rapidly evolving STEM landscape.  Faculty development was also a cornerstone. Several speakers developed teaching methods and high impact practices (HIPS) seminars to equip biological science faculty to help an array of students for increased scale of the program to the broader department.

Community Engagement

The LEAPS and BOUNDS SSTEM program created a collaborative environment through student clubs and colloquium.  For example, the PACTS club (Pursuing All Careers Together in STEM) and the pre-Health club provided students with peer support and leadership development.  The Biology Colloquium gathered faculty and students together where they were able to share research and be provided with networking opportunities and access to guest speakers.  This highlights the strength of connections between the college and the broader scientific community.

Broader Societal Contributions

The LEAPS and BOUNDS SSTEM program embodied a culture of inclusivity and excellence.  It directly addressing the national need for a diverse STEM workforce and its initiatives have empowered students from underrepresented groups to envision and achieve success in fields where they have historically been marginalized.  The program has also developed a structured advising framework to support community college students, ensuring they receive proper guidance and timely graduations.  LEAPS and BOUNDS not only improved individual student outcomes but also enriched Seminole State College’s academic ecosystem through collaborations with industry partners, academic institutions, and nonprofit organizations.

Scalability and Sustainability

Seminole State College is preparing to expand the program’s impact. Plans include applying for additional funding, deepening industry collaborations, and integrating undergraduate research and advanced technologies like artificial intelligence to enhance educational outcomes.  It has already impacted the faculty center for teaching and learning by prompting them to develop a HIP ambassador program. 

 

Conclusion

Seminole State College’s LEAPS and BOUNDS S-STEM program exemplifies the strategic support, transformative power of education, and sets a benchmark for excellence in STEM education. By combining financial support, appropriate advising and mentorship, peer cohorts, and immersive research experiences, the program has empowered students to break down barriers and create pathways to success for themselves and others.  The National Science Foundation’s investment in this program has not only uplifted individuals but also contributed to the broader advancement of the STEM workforce, ensuring a more inclusive and innovative future for all.


Last Modified: 04/14/2025
Modified by: Maya P Byfield
